name: Development Process, Standards, and Tools
description: a. Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to follow a documented development process that: 1. Explicitly addresses security and privacy requirements; 2. Identifies the standards and tools used in the development process; 3. Documents the specific tool options and tool configurations used in the development process; and 4. Documents, manages, and ensures the integrity of changes to the process and/or tools used in development; and b. Review the development process, standards, tools, tool options, and tool configurations [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] to determine if the process, standards, tools, tool options and tool configurations selected and employed can satisfy the following security and privacy requirements: [Assignment: organization-defined security and privacy requirements].
supplemental_guidance: Development tools include programming languages and computer-aided design systems. Reviews of development processes include the use of maturity models to determine the potential effectiveness of such processes. Maintaining the integrity of changes to tools and processes facilitates effective supply chain risk assessment and mitigation.

attack_techniques.name: Valid Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Requiring documented development processes that address security ensures that valid accounts used in development environments follow secure credential management practices, reducing exposure of development credentials.

attack_techniques.name: Steal Application Access Token
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process standards that mandate secure token handling, short-lived credentials, and proper OAuth implementation reduce the risk of application access tokens being exposed during development.

attack_techniques.name: Unsecured Credentials
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development standards requiring secure credential management—prohibiting hardcoded secrets, mandating vault integration, and enforcing pre-commit scanning—prevent unsecured credentials from entering codebases.

attack_techniques.name: Default Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process requirements that mandate changing default credentials, implementing secure initial configurations, and documenting all default accounts reduce the risk of default account exploitation in production.

attack_techniques.name: Local Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Secure development standards requiring unique service account credentials, prohibiting shared local accounts, and mandating credential rotation prevent local account credential exposure through development artifacts.

attack_techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process controls that mandate least-privilege cloud IAM configurations, short-lived cloud credentials, and secure service identity management reduce cloud account exposure from insecure development practices.

attack_techniques.name: Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process standards that enforce dependency integrity verification, software composition analysis, and trusted package registry usage directly mitigate supply chain compromise through development tool and dependency tampering.

attack_techniques.name: Code Repositories
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development standards that enforce access controls on code repositories, require branch protection, and mandate code review workflows prevent adversaries from collecting sensitive code through improperly secured repositories.

attack_techniques.name: Credentials In Files
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process requirements that enforce pre-commit secret scanning, prohibit credentials in source code, and mandate external secret storage prevent credentials from being committed to files in code repositories.

attack_techniques.name: Credentials in Registry
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Secure development standards that prohibit storing credentials in registry values and mandate secure configuration management prevent credential exposure through registry-stored development configuration data.

attack_techniques.name: Private Keys
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process controls that enforce hardware-backed key storage, prohibit private keys in source repositories, and mandate certificate lifecycle management prevent private key exposure in development artifacts.

attack_techniques.name: Group Policy Preferences
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development standards that prohibit embedding credentials in Group Policy Preferences and mandate LAPS or certificate-based authentication prevent credential exposure through GPP-based configuration management.

attack_techniques.name: AS-REP Roasting
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Secure development processes that enforce Kerberos pre-authentication requirements and mandate strong service account configurations during deployment prevent AS-REP roasting vulnerabilities from reaching production.

attack_techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Development process standards that enforce secure DLL loading practices, validate library dependencies, and implement manifest-based binding prevent DLL side-loading vulnerabilities from being introduced during development.
